#Text=CHAPTER XIII
#Text=Long before daylight the camp at Nephi was astir .
#Text=The cattle were driven out to water and pasture .
#Text=While the men unchained the wheels and drew the wagons apart and clear for yoking in , the women cooked forty breakfasts over forty fires .
#Text=The children , in the chill of dawn , clustered about the fires , sharing places , here and there , with the last relief of the night-watch waiting sleepily for coffee .
#Text=It requires time to get a large train such as ours under way , for its speed is the speed of the slowest .
#Text=So the sun was an hour high and the day was already uncomfortably hot when we rolled out of Nephi and on into the sandy barrens .
#Text=No inhabitant of the place saw us off .
#Text=All chose to remain indoors , thus making our departure as ominous as they had made our arrival the night before .
#Text=Again it was long hours of parching heat and biting dust , sage-brush and sand , and a land accursed .

#Text=No dwellings of men , neither cattle nor fences , nor any sign of human kind , did we encounter all that day ; and at night we made our wagon-circle beside an empty stream , in the damp sand of which we dug many holes that filled slowly with water seepage .
#Text=Our subsequent journey is always a broken experience to me .
#Text=We made camp so many times , always with the wagons drawn in circle , that to my child mind a weary long time passed after Nephi .
#Text=But always , strong upon all of us , was that sense of drifting to an impending and certain doom .
#Text=We averaged about fifteen miles a day .
#Text=I know , for my father had said it was sixty miles to Fillmore , the next Mormon settlement , and we made three camps on the way .
#Text=This meant four days of travel .
#Text=From Nephi to the last camp of which I have any memory we must have taken two weeks or a little less .
#Text=At Fillmore the inhabitants were hostile , as all had been since Salt Lake .
#Text=They laughed at us when we tried to buy food , and were not above taunting us with being Missourians .
#Text=When we entered the place , hitched before the largest house of the dozen houses that composed the settlement were two saddle-horses , dusty , streaked with sweat , and drooping .

#Text=The old man I have mentioned , the one with long , sunburnt hair and buckskin shirt and who seemed a sort of aide or lieutenant to father , rode close to our wagon and indicated the jaded saddle-animals with a cock of his head .
#Text=" Not sparin ' horseflesh , Captain , " he muttered in a low voice .
#Text=" An ' what in the name of Sam Hill are they hard-riding for if it ai n't for us ?
#Text=It was at Fillmore that I saw a man that I was to see again .
#Text=He was a tall , broad-shouldered man , well on in middle age , with all the evidence of good health and immense strength -- strength not alone of body but of will .
#Text=Unlike most men I was accustomed to about me , he was smooth-shaven .
#Text=Several days ' growth of beard showed that he was already well-grayed .
#Text=His mouth was unusually wide , with thin lips tightly compressed as if he had lost many of his front teeth .
#Text=His nose was large , square , and thick .
#Text=So was his face square , wide between the cheekbones , underhung with massive jaws , and topped with a broad , intelligent forehead .
#Text=And the eyes , rather small , a little more than the width of an eye apart , were the bluest blue I had ever seen .
#Text=It was at the flour-mill at Fillmore that I first saw this man .
#Text=Father , with several of our company , had gone there to try to buy flour , and I , disobeying my mother in my curiosity to see more of our enemies , had tagged along unperceived .
#Text=This man was one of four or five who stood in a group with the miller during the interview .
#Text=" You seen that smooth-faced old cuss ?
